And today we are talking
about backup and restore
with DynamoDB tables.

There are two types of
backups offered with DynamoDB,
on-demand backups and continuous backups
with point-in-time recovery.

Both types of backups have
three things in common,
all data is encrypted at rest,

the ability to restore
to another AWS Region,

and being able to back up
petabytes worth of data

with no performance
impacts on your base table.

First up is continuous backups
with point-in-time recovery.
These are continuous incremental backups

that allow you to
restore to any one second
in the last 35 days.

There is nothing to maintain
and no scheduling required.

More than likely, you
should have a good reason
to not have continuous backups enabled
on your production tables.
My favorite feature of continuous backups
is that, beyond simple restores,

is it enables exporting
of your table's data to S3

and other services without
affecting the performance
of your base table in DynamoDB.

This enables you to run
services like Athena
and Machine Learning over that same data
to make the data even more useful to you.
On-demand backups are used
to create a full backup of your table,
a snapshot, if you will.
It provides long-term retention
and meets regulatory compliance needs.

On-demand backups can be
cataloged, discoverable,
and retained until explicitly deleted.

You can create on-demand
backups via the AWS console,
API, CLI, or the AWS Backup service.

For on-demand backups
of your DynamoDB table,

the AWS Backup service should
be your go-to mechanism.

AWS Backup service offers
end-to-end management
of on-demand backups for DynamoDB.

It automates scheduled backups
and retention enforcement.

You can copy backups between
AWS Regions and accounts

as well as restore backups
between AWS Regions.

You can store backups
in encrypted AWS Vaults,

which you can secure
multiple different ways,

including an encryption
key that's different

from the DynamoDB base
table encryption key.
My second favorite feature of AWS Backups

is being able to automatically
move older backups
to a cold storage tier
and thus save on storage costs.
And finally, your backups inherit tags
from your source DynamoDB tables,

allowing you to use those
tags to set permissions

and service control
policies on your backups.
